Fig. 1 (A) NH3-SCR activities (B) N2 selectivities of the catalysts. Reaction conditions: 600 ppm NO, 600 ppm NH3, 5% O2, 5% H2O, balance Ar, GHSV = 108,000 h−1. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 SO2 resistance of MnTiOx and MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalysts at 150 ℃. Reaction conditions: 600 ppm NO, 600 ppm NH3, 5% O2, 5% H2O (when used), 100 ppm SO2 (when used), balance Ar, GHSV = 108,000 h−1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (A) Mn 2p (B) O 1s and (C) Ti 2p XPS spectra of the catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 NH3-TPD profiles of the catalysts. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 NO oxidation over the catalysts. Reaction conditions: 600 ppm NO, 5% O2, 5% H2O, balance Ar, GHSV = 108,000 h−1. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 DRIFT spectra for NH3 adsorption over (A) MnTiOx (B)MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalysts at different temperature. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 DRIFT spectra for NO + O2 co-adsorption over (A) MnTiOx (B)MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalysts at different temperature. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 DRIFT spectra of (A) MnTiOx (B) MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalysts exposed to 600 ppm NH3 followed by exposure to 600 ppm NO + 5% O2 as a function of time at 150 ℃. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 DRIFT spectra of (A) MnTiOx (B) MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalysts exposed to 600 ppm NO + 5% O2 followed by exposure to 600 ppm NH3 as a function of time at 150 ℃. Fig. 11 Table 1 Textural parameters of the catalysts. Table 1 Samples BET surface area (m2/g) Pore volume (cm3/g) Average pore diameter (nm) MnTiOx 51.8 0.066 3.79 SbTiOx 54.4 0.064 3.80 MnSbTiOx-0.1 64.1 0.075 3.81 MnSbTiOx-0.2 68.5 0.079 3.83 MnSbTiOx-0.25 64.3 0.080 3.82 Table 2 Surface acidities of the catalysts. Table 2 Samples Surface acidity (mmol/g) MnTiOx 0.032 SbTiOx 0.019 MnSbTiOx-0.1 0.052 MnSbTiOx-0.2 0.105 MnSbTiOx-0.25 0.081 Enhancement of the NH3-SCR catalytic activity of MnTiOx catalyst by the introduction of Sb Rui-tang Guo a b c ⁎ Xiao Sun a b Jian Liu a b Wei-guo Pan a b ⁎ Ming-yuan Li a b Shu-ming Liu a b Peng Sun a b Shuai-wei Liu a b a School of Energy Source and Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai University of Electric Power, Shanghai, 200090, PR China School of Energy Source and Mechanical Engineering Shanghai University of Electric Power Shanghai 200090 PR China b Shanghai Engineering Research Center of Power Generation Environment Protection, Shanghai, 200090, PR China Shanghai Engineering Research Center of Power Generation Environment Protection Shanghai 200090 PR China c Shanghai Institute of Pollution Control and Ecological Security, Shanghai, 200092, PR China Shanghai Institute of Pollution Control and Ecological Security Shanghai 200092 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: School of Energy Source and Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai University of Electric Power, Shanghai, 200090, PR China. School of Energy Source and Mechanical Engineering Shanghai University of Electric Power Shanghai 200090 PR China Graphical abstract Sb was used as the additive to enhance the NH3-SCR performance of MnTiOx catalyst. Experimental results revealed that MnSbTiOx-0.2 demonstrated outstanding NH3-SCR activity in a wide temperature window (100–400 ℃) and high resistance to SO2. Characterization results indicated the introduction of Sb into MnTiOx catalyst could improve the dispersity of active species and generate more surface acid sites, Mn4+ and surface adsorbed oxygen species. In situ DRIFT spectra proved that the presence of Sb in MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst could form new Brønsted acid sites, along with the increased surface Lewis acidity. The improved adsorption of NH3 and NOx species over MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst had a stimulating effect on the NH3-SCR reaction over it through Langmuir−Hinshelwood (L-H) route. Moreover, Sb species in MnSbTiOx-0.2 could improve the reactivities of ad-NH3 and ad-NOx species in SCR reaction. All these factors contributed to the excellent performance of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst. Keywords NOx SCR MnTiOx Catalyst Sb Activity Characterization 1 Introduction Owing to its prominent damage to ecological environment and human health, NOx removal is one of the most important topics in environmental protection filed. For this propose, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) removal of NOx using NH3 as the reductant displays high DeNOx performance and widely applied in industrial field such as coal-fired power stations and diesel engines [1,2]. As the representative of commercialized SCR catalyst, V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalyst exhibits high SCR performance in 300–400 ℃ [3]. However, the evitable drawbacks linked to this catalyst including effective conversion SO2 into SO3 and the poisonous VOx species bring about great restrictions on its prospective application [4–6]. Therefore, new SCR catalysts based on some other transition metal oxides (including MnOx, CeOx, CuOx and FeOx, etc.) have been developed for the replacement of V-based catalyst [7–11]. Among them, Mn-based catalyst possesses outstanding low-temperature SCR performance and is regarded as one of the promising alternatives for future utilization [12–16]. The presence of Mn species with different valence in manganese oxides is crucial for completing the redox cycle in SCR reaction process [17,18]. Deng et al. [19] found that the facet preference of TiO2 support greatly affected the deNOx ability of MnOx/TiO2 catalyst. Meng et al. [20] revealed that Sm was an effective promoter of MnOx catalyst for SCR reaction. Similar promotion effect of Nd on MnOx catalyst had also been observed in our recent study [21]. Chen et al. [22] also indicated that the redox cycle between Mn and Cr ions brought about the high activity of Cr(0.4)–MnOx catalyst. Nevertheless, most of the studies were performed under relatively low GHSV value (<10, 000 h−1), exhibiting a relatively narrow activity temperature window. Therefore, developing new Mn-based SCR catalyst with high activity and temperature adaptability is still of great necessity. In our previous study [23], Sb was used as the modifier of Mn/TiO2 catalyst for improving its Na resistance. Experimental results displayed that Sb-decorated Mn/TiO2 catalyst was of high SCR activity in 100–220 ℃. However, the role of Sb additive on the SCR process over Mn-based catalyst in a wide reaction temperature range still needs further investigation. In present study, MnSbTiOx catalysts with different Sb/Mn molar ratios were synthetized and used in NH3-SCR reaction, the relationship between the excellent SCR performance and the physico-chemical properties would be explored by means of the different characterization techniques. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis MnTiOx and MnSbTiOx catalysts used in present work were synthesized by the sol-gel method. Manganese nitrate, butyl titanate and antimony nitrate were the sources of Mn, Ti and Sb species respectively. The molar ratio of Mn/Ti in MnTiOx catalyst was kept at 0.2. When preparing the catalyst, manganese nitrate (0.02 mol), butyl titanate (0.1 mol), butyl titanate (2.9 mol), deionized water (1.9 mol) and nitric acid (0.1 mol) were mixed adequately until the formation of a yellowish sol. After a drying process at 80 ℃ for 24 h, the sol was transferred into xerogel. Next then, the xerogel was put into a calcination process in air at 500 ℃ for 5 h, the final MnTiOx catalyst formed. A similar procedure was used for the preparation of MnSbTiOx catalyst samples. Ethylene glycol was used for solving antimony nitrate. The MnSbTiOx catalyst samples were named as MnSbTiOx-y, where y was the molar ratio of Sb/Mn. Moreover, SbTiOx catalyst (Sb/Ti molar ratio = 0.2) was prepared and used for comparison. 2.2 Characterizations For the determination of the catalyst textural properties, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were recorded at −196 ℃ on a micromeritics (Quantachrome Autosorb-1). The specific surface area and the pore size distribution were evaluated according to Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) methods respectively. Before the textural property measurement, the catalyst sample was subjected to a degassing treatment in a vacuum at 300 ℃ for 4 h. XRD patterns were obtained on an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advance, CuKα radiation). The surface elements and their valence states were identified by XPS analysis using a Thermo ESCALAB 250 spectrometer operated at 150 W. The binding energy shift calibration was based upon that of C 1s peak (284.6 eV). To reveal the redox behavior of each catalyst sample, H2-TPR study was conducted on a chemisorption analyzer (Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-C) with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Before the TPR experiment, a certain amount of sample (50 mg) was put into the N2 pretreatment at 400 ℃ for 1 h. When performing TPR run, the samples was heated at a constant rate (10 ℃/min) in the mixed gas flow of 6% H2/N2 (30 mL/min) from 100 to 800 ℃. NH3-TPD study was also accomplished on the same chemisorption analyzer. At first, 0.1 g catalyst sample was placed into the quartz reactor and pretreated at 400 ℃ in pure He for 1 h, followed by a saturation treatment with a 4% NH3/He mixed gas (30 mL/min) for 30 min. Then TPD test was conducted by warming the sample at a steady rate (10 ℃/min) from 100 to 500 ℃. The in situ DRIFT spectra were recorded on a FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet iS50) with a MCT detector. Firstly, the catalyst was heated in the DRIFT cell at 400 ℃ for 0.5 h in the atmosphere of 20% O2/N2 gas flow, and then cooled to 50 ℃. The background DRIFT spectra were collected at different temperature, along with an automatic subtraction process from the sample spectra. The reaction conditions were adopted for DRIFT study: 300 mL/min total flowrate, 600 ppm of NH3, or/and 600 ppm of NO + 5% of O2, and N2 balance. The spectra record was performed by accumulating of 100 scans with a 4 cm−1 resolution. 2.3 Catalytic activity test SCR activity measurement was accomplished in a fixed-bed reactor (i. d. = 8 mm) using 0.55 cm3 sample (80–100 mesh). The simulated flue gas was consisted of NO (600 ppm), NH3 (600 ppm), O2 (5%), H2O(5%), SO2 (100 ppm, only for SO2 resistance test) and balance Ar. The flowrate of each gas component was controlled by a mass flow controller with a steady total flowrate (1 L/min), resulting in a GHSV value of 108, 000 h−1. The components of the effluent flue gas (including NO, NO2, NH3 and N2O) were measured by a FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Nicolet iS 50) connected with a 0.2 dm3 gas cell. In each experimental run, the SCR reaction reached its steady state after about 1 h. Then NOx conversion and N2 selectivity values could be determined via: (1) N O x c o n v e r s i o n = [ N O x ] i n - [ N O x ] o u t [ N O x ] i n × 100 % (2) N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y = 1 - 2 N 2 O o u t N O x i n + N H 3 i n - N O x o u t - N H 3 o u t × 100 % NO oxidation activity of each catalyst sample was also evaluated under the similar experimental conditions; nevertheless, NH3 was not contained in the inlet gas stream. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance Fig. 1 (A) displays the SCR activities of MnTiOx, MnSbTiOx-0.1, MnSbTiOx-0.2, MnSbTiOx-0.25 and SbTiOx catalysts. Evidently, the SCR activity of SbTiOx catalyst is very low, which is less than 40% in 100–400 ℃. MnTiOx catalyst exhibits a much higher SCR activity compared with SbTiOx catalyst. However, a sharp activity drop is present when the reaction temperature is over 300 ℃. Most obviously, the decoration of MnTiOx catalyst with Sb has an obvious promotion effect on its SCR activity, especially for MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst, it possesses a wide T90 temperature window of 138–367 ℃. It seems that further increasing the Sb content in MnSbTiOx catalyst is not favorable to SCR reaction, the activity temperature window becomes slightly narrower for MnSbTiOx-0.25 catalyst. Besides that, the presence of Sb in MnSbTiOx catalysts is also helpful to improving their N2 selectivities, as shown in Fig. 1(B). 3.2 SO2/H2O resistance The high sensitivity of Mn-based SCR catalyst to SO2 and H2O is a great barrier for its industrial application [24,25]. So the SCR activity of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst in the presence of 100 ppm SO2 and 5% H2O was also investigated, as illustrated in Fig. 2 . Evidently, the introduction of 100 ppm SO2 and 5%H2O into the simulated flue gas causes a remarkable activity drop over MnTiOx catalyst, which decreases from 60.2% to about 28.0% in 36 h. In marked contrast, a slight activity decrease from 97.3% to about 85.0% could be detected on MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst under the same experimental conditions. Noticeably, the NOx conversion over MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst basically restores after the stop of SO2/H2O supply. So MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst has perfect SO2/H2O resistance, which makes it more competitive in actual industrial application. 3.3 BET and XRD Table 1 lists the textural parameters of each catalyst sample. From Table 1, the introduction of Sb species into MnTiOx catalyst could increase its specific surface area, and MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst possesses the largest BET surface area among the five samples (68.5 m2/g), which is beneficial to the adsorption of reactants in NH3-SCR reaction. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts. Only the diffraction peaks representing anatase TiO2 and rutile TiO2 could be detected, thus Mn and Sb species are well dispersed or present in amorphous phase [26,27]. Noticeably, the peak intensities in the pattern of MnSbTiOx catalyst samples decrease with increasing Sb content, suggesting the decrease of TiO2 crystallinity after the doping of Sb. Therefore, there are strong interactions among Mn, Sb and Ti species in MnSbTiOx catalysts, leading to the increase of specific surface area. Moreover, more surface defects could be formed with the decrease of TiO2 crystallinity, resulting in the generation of more surface adsorbed oxygen species. 3.4 XPS The concentrations of surface elements and their chemical states on a SCR catalyst play a major aspect in SCR reaction, which could be determined by XPS analysis. The results of XPS analysis are displayed in Fig. 4 . Fig. 4(A) presents the Mn 2p XPS spectra for MnTiOx, MnSbTiOx-0.1, MnSbTiOx-0.2 and MnSbTiOx-0.25 catalysts. The two main peaks located at about 642.5 and 653.5 eV could be ascribed to Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2 respectively [28,29]. After a peak-fitting deconvolution procedure, the two main peaks could be further assigned to different Mn species: Mn2+(B. E. = 640.4 eV), Mn3+ (B. E. = 642.0 eV) and Mn4+ (B. E. = 644.0 eV). The ratios of Mn4+/Mn for MnTiOx catalyst is 24.9%. Obviously, the introduction of Sb would result in the increase of Mn4+/Mn ratio. The corresponding ratio of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst is 39.2%, which is massively higher than that of MnTiOx catalyst. The O 1s XPS spectra for MnTiOx, SbTiOx, MnSbTiOx-0.1, MnSbTiOx-0.2 and MnSbTiOx-0.25 catalysts are displayed in Fig. 4(B), which could be split into two characteristic peaks of different oxygen species: lattice oxygen (B.E. ≈ 530.0 eV, denoted as Oα), and surface adsorbed oxygen(like O 2 2 - , O - , etc., B.E. ≈ 530.0 eV, denoted as Oβ) [29,30]. Clearly, Sb species contained in MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst could generate more surface adsorbed oxygen on it. It is evident that the Oβ/(Oα + Oβ) for MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst is as high as 30.1%, which is the highest value among that of the samples. It is well known that Mn4+ could promotion the redox reaction such as NO oxidation. Moreover, surface adsorbed oxygen could effectively oxidize NO to NO2 owing to its high mobility. Thus NOx removal via the “fast SCR” route (NO + NO2 + 2NH3 = 2N2 + 3H2O) could be accelerated efficiently [31,32]. Smirniotis et al. [33,34] also indicated that the high Mn4+/Mn 3+ atomic ratio is a key factor for the high deNOx efficiency over manganese-based catalyst in low-temperature range. So the enrichment of Mn4+ and surface adsorbed oxygen species over MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst is propitious to the NH3-SCR reaction over it. The XPS spectra of Ti 2p for MnTiOx, SbTiOx, MnSbTiOx-0.1, MnSbTiOx-0.2 and MnSbTiOx-0.25 catalysts are demonstrated in Fig. 4(C). Two double peaks (Ti 2p1/2 and Ti 2p3/2) appear. Compared with the spectra of MnTiOx catalyst, a binding energy shift to lower value is visible for the Sb-doped catalyst samples, reveling that some Ti4+ is reduced to Ti3+ as a result of the strong interaction among Mn, Sb and Ti species [35,36]. 3.5 H2-TPR The redox properties of MnTiOx, SbTiOx, MnSbTiOx-0.1, MnSbTiOx-0.2 and MnSbTiOx-0.25 catalysts were evaluated by H2-TPR analysis, as shown in Fig. 5 . In the profile of SbTiOx catalyst, there are two reduction peaks at 614 and 680 ℃, which could be attributed to the reduction of Sb5+ → Sb3+ and Sb3+ → Sb° respectively [37,38]. For the profile of MnTiOx, three reduction peaks appear at 283, 382 and 523 ℃, they represent the three reduction steps of Mn4+ → Mn3+, Mn3+ → Mn2+ and Mn2+ → Mn° respectively [39,40]. As for the profiles of Sb-modified catalyst samples, the former two peak mean the continuous reduction steps of Mn4+ → Mn3+ → Mn2+, and the third one is related to the co-reduction step of Mn2+ → Mn° and Sb5+ → Sb3+ [38–40]. The last one above 600 ℃ could be owing to the reduction of Sb3+ → Sb° [38]. Obviously, a reduction peak shift to lower temperature could be found on the profiles of Sb-modified MnTiOx catalyst samples compared with that of MnTiOx catalyst, suggesting the increased reducibility after Sb decoration. 3.6 NH3-TPD NH3 adsorption is crucial for SCR reaction [41], which is closely related to the surface acidity of SCR catalyst. By virtue of NH3-TPD analysis, the surface acidity of each sample was investigated and the profiles are exhibited in Fig. 6 . From Fig. 6, only tiny amounts of NH3 species desorbed from the surface of SbTiOx catalyst, suggesting its low NH3 adsorption capacity. For the profile of MnTiOx catalyst, there is a wide peak lasting from ∼150 ℃ to ∼450 ℃ in it, thus the surface acid sites of MnTiOx catalyst displays different thermal stability. Obviously, the NH3 desorption peak becomes wider and stronger after the addition of Sb on MnTiOx catalyst, especially for the desorption peak in the profile of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst, which covers from 100 to 400 ℃, demonstrating the coexistence of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [42–44]. Thus the modification of MnTiOx catalyst with Sb could form new acid sites for NH3 adsorption, which is further confirmed by the quantified surface acidity (Table 2 ). 3.7 NO oxidation The catalytic activities for NO oxidation over MnTiOx, SbTiOx, MnSbTiOx-0.1, MnSbTiOx-0.2 and MnSbTiOx-0.25 catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . From Fig. 7, it is distinct that the NO oxidation activity over SbTiOx catalyst is very low, which keeps at about 10% in 100–400 ℃. Correspondingly, SbTiOx catalyst possesses poor low-temperature SCR activity due to the inefficient conversion from NO to NO2. The activity curves of other catalyst samples demonstrate a parabolic, which is an indication of the conversion from kinetically-controlled regime to thermodynamically controlled regime [45,46]. In addition, MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst is more impactful for NO oxidation compared with the other samples. The formation of more NO2 over MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst is propitious to NOx reduction over it at low-temperature range. 3.8 In situ DRIFT spectra 3.8.1 NH3 adsorption To ascertain the nature of surface acid sites on MnTiOx and MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalysts, the NH3 adsorption DRIFT spectra over them at different temperature were recorded and given in Fig. 8 . From the spectra of MnTiOx catalyst (Fig. 8(A)), only two bands are visible at 1600 and 1300 cm−1 respectively, both of them are owing to the NH3 species adsorbed on Lewis acid sites [47–49]. For the spectra of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst, there are five as-NH3 bands could be observed, including NH3 species linked to Lewis acid sites (1598,1306 and 1165 cm−1) and N H 4 + species adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites (1490, 1399 cm−1) [50–54]. It seems that the existence of Sb in MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst could generate Brønsted acid sites, furthermore, the band intensities in the spectra of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst are much stronger, and thus more adsorbed NH3 species are available over MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst. Moreover, the entire bands become weaker with temperature, suggesting the desorption of ad-NH3 species at high temperature. It should be noticed that the surface acidity of MnTiOx catalyst is much lower than that of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst. Thus nearly all the ad-NH3 speices over MnTiOx catalyst disappear at 300–350 ℃, leading to the sharp activity decrease above 300 ℃ (Fig. 1(A)). 3.8.2 NO + O2 co-adsorption Fig. 9 illustrates the DRIFT spectra for NO+O2 co-adsorption over MnTiOx and MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalysts. In the spectra of MnTiOx catalyst (Fig. 9(A)), four bands are detected, revealing the existence of adsorbed NO2 species (1612 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1547 cm−1), monodentate nitrate (1290 cm−1) and bridged nitrate (1238 cm−1) [30,52–56]. After the doping with Sb, five bands are available in the DRIFT spectra of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst (Fig. 9(B)), they belong to adsorbed NO2 species (1605 cm−1), bidentate nitrate (1544 cm-1), monodentate nitrate (1485 and 1286 cm−1) and bridged nitrate (1231 cm−1) respectively [30,52–56]. From the newly-formed band at 1485 cm−1 and the increased band intensities, it may be concluded that the modification MnTiOx catalyst with Sb could generate more ad-NOx species on it. Similar with that in the DRIFT spectra of NH3 adsorption, all the bands become weaker with temperature due to the desorption effect at high temperature. 3.8.3 Reaction between NOx and the preadsorbed NH3 species To confirm the aspect of the preadsorbed NH3 species in the SCR reactions over MnTiOx and MnSbTiOx-0.2, each catalyst sample was firstly treated with 600 ppm NH3/N2 for 30 min, followed by a N2 purging for 15 min. Next then, 600 ppm NO and 5% O2/N2 were entered into the IR cell and the time-dependent DRIFT spectra were took down, as presented in Fig. 10 . From Fig. 10(A), the pretreatment of MnTiOx catalyst with NH3 generated two NH3 adsorption bands (1600 and 1300 cm−1) in its spectra, and the two bands decreased gradually after the introduction of NO+O2, it took more than 10 min for the completely consumption of preadsorbed NH3 species over MnTiOx catalyst. With the vanishment of the preadsorbed NH3 species, several bands of adsorbed NOx species came out and grew with time, revealing that the adsorbed NH3 species were replaced by them. For the DRIFT spectra of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst under the same reaction conditions (Fig. 10(B)), the situation was quite different. All the preadsorbed NH3 species disappeared after the supply of NO+O2 for 2 min. Thus the modification of MnTiOx catalyst by Sb could effectively enhance the reactivity of the preadsorbed NH3 species. And all the preadsorbed NH3 species over the two samples were involved in NH3-SCR reaction. 3.8.4 Reaction between NH3 and the preadsorbed NOx species From another side, NH3 and NOx were introduced to the IR cell in an opposite order, and the DRIFT spectra for this process over MnTiOx and MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalysts were recorded and demonstrated in Fig. 11 . From Fig. 11(A), the exposure of MnTiOx catalyst to 600 ppm NO + 5% O2 formed several NOx adsorption bands in its DRIFT spectra. As shown in Fig. 11(A), all the ad-NOx species over MnTiOx catalyst were consumed in the reaction, however, the reactivity of them are relatively low, the two bands at 1612 and 1290 cm−1 were still observable after the introduction of NH3 for 10 min. Next then, NH3 species were adsorbed on the surface of MnTiOx catalyst, as indicated by the formation and growth of the corresponding bands in the DRIFT spectra. Besides that, the ad-NH3 bands in Fig. 11(A) are quite different from that in Fig. 8(A). The two bands at 1607 and 1281 cm−1 belong to NH3 species over Lewis acid sites [47,53]. The band at 1537 cm−1 could be attributed to NH2 species owing to the oxidation of NH3 by adsorbed oxygen [57]. The other two bands at 1479 and 1380 cm-1 should represent N H 4 + species over Brønsted acid sites [53,58].The formed H2O in NH3-SCR reaction could generate hydroxyl groups on catalyst, which could serve as Brønsted acid sites for the adsorption of N H 4 + species [36,59]. In remarkable contrast, no ad-NOx species are visible in the spectra of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst after the contact with NH3 for 2 min (Fig. 11(B)), suggesting the high reactivity of these species. Thus the presence of Sb species in MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst had an activation effect on the adsorbed reactants in SCR reaction. Combined with the results of Sections 3.8.3 and 3.8.4, both the ad-NH3 species and the ad-NOx species were the participants of SCR reactions over MnTiOx and MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalysts. 3.9 Promotion mechanism As discussed in the forgoing results, the introduction of proper amount of Sb into MnTiOx catalyst could generate more a-NH3 and ad-NOx species on its surface. After the addition of Sb, highly active ad-NH3 and ad-NOx species in SCR reaction could be found on MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst. Moreover, the facilitated NO oxidation is also available on the surface of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst owing to the enhanced reducibility and the formation of more surface adsorbed oxygen. And all the ad-species over MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst are promptly consumed in the NH3-SCR reaction process (Figs. 10(B) and 11(B)). All these features indicate that the promoted NH3-SCR reaction over MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst is mainly through the Langmuir−Hinshelwood (L-H) route [60,61], as described by: (3) N H 3 g → N H 4 + a o n B r ø n s t e d a c i d s i t e s (4) N H 3 g → N H 3 a o n L e w i s a c i d s i t e s (5) O 2 ( g ) → 2 O ( a ) (6) N O g + O ( a ) → N O 2 ( a ) (7) N H 4 + a + e - + N O 2 a → N H 4 N O 2 a → N 2 + 2 H 2 O (8) 2 N H 3 a + N O 2 a + N O g → 2 N 2 + 3 H 2 O 4 Conclusions Sb modification could effectively improve the SCR capability and SO2 resistance of MnTiOx catalyst. MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst displayed a NOx conversion over 90% in 138–367, accompanied with perfect SO2 resistance. Characterization results proved the formation of more reducible species and the generation of more Mn4+ and surface adsorbed oxygen species after the introduction of Sb into MnTiOx catalyst, which could remarkably enhance NO oxidation. Moreover, more adsorbed NH3 and adsorbed NOx species with high reactivity could be found on the surface of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst. Following as an effect, the NH3-SCR reaction over MnSbTiOx-0.2 could be accelerated through the the L-H route. References [1] S. Andreoli F.A. Deorsola C. Galletti R. Pirone Chem. Eng. coredata.dc:description: Sb was used as the additive to enhance the NH3-SCR performance of MnTiOx catalyst. Experimental results revealed that MnSbTiOx-0.2 demonstrated outstanding NH3-SCR activity in a wide temperature window (100–400 ℃) and high resistance to SO2. Characterization results indicated the introduction of Sb into MnTiOx catalyst could improve the dispersity of active species and generate more surface acid sites, Mn4+ and surface adsorbed oxygen species. In situ DRIFT spectra proved that the presence of Sb in MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst could form new Brønsted acid sites, along with the increased surface Lewis acidity. The improved adsorption of NH3 and NOx species over MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst had a stimulating effect on the NH3-SCR reaction over it through Langmuir−Hinshelwood (L-H) route. Moreover, Sb species in MnSbTiOx-0.2 could improve the reactivities of ad-NH3 and ad-NOx species in SCR reaction. All these factors contributed to the excellent performance of MnSbTiOx-0.2 catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancement of the NH3-SCR catalytic activity of MnTiOx catalyst by the introduction of Sb
